results.title: Whales, dolphins and men (D)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Dolphins and whales share a common ancestor; yet dolphins are the darlings of the public, while whales are the victims of commercial exploitation. The dolphin is considered man’s friend and playmate, the whale continues to be a victim of exploitation and face a very real danger of extinction. Discusses scientific studies of these marine mammals. Note: Some scenes may be offensive to animal lovers.

results.title: The Fat in the fire
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
A new theory on why people get fat. Research has shown that babies have special fat cells called brown fat, which decline as the human grows up. It is suggested that brown fat may continue to play an important role in determining the weight of adults. Written by Martin Freeth and narrated by Phillip James.

results.title: The Mondragon experiment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Mondragon in the Basque region of Spain, is an industrial town where more than 80 factories are co-operatively owned by the workers. All this has been created with scant help from a suspicious government and no funds from stock-market investors. It has run successfully for twenty-five years. The workers run the factories and appoint the managers, run their own bank, technical college and research laboratories. In Britain, workers and management have been at loggerheads since the Industrial Revolution. Examines the feasability of Britain following the same road to prosperity. Narrated by Alexander John

results.title: Way Out
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
London Transport, the world’s biggest urban transport system, is today widely regarded as being unreliable, expensive and slow. The film investigates how London Transport may be able to improve services

results.title: A Touch of sensitivity
results.creator_credit: Stephen Rose and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
A sense of touch is vital to our well-being and yet we often ignore it to our cost. This film reports on recent research in Britain and America which has led to some remarkable findings.

results.title: Survival of the fastest
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Page, Dick Gilling and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Highlights the evolution of the motorcycle from a primitive machine into a gleaming, glamorous, sophisticated piece of engineering. Scenes at Mallory Park and the 1979 Isle of Man TT follow the fortunes of Barry Sheene, Mike Hailwood and Ron Haslam and their machines. Goes into the research and development, technical and commercial problems, and how Britain and Europe are facing up to the Japanese challenge. Narrated by Tony Britton.

results.title: Square pegs
results.creator_credit: John Mansfield and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Today, applying for a job often means submitting to innumerable tests, not only of ability and intelligence, but also of personality. But just how valid are these tests? This program examines some of the techniques used by the boom industry of Management Selection and follows two candidates through their ordeal.

results.title: The Spike
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Documentary which explains the disease of epilepsy and looks at research which is being done into its causes and how to treat it. Includes extensive interviews with epilepsy sufferers who describe their symptoms and their feelings about the disease and the social stigma attached to it. Presented and narrated by Dr Peter Fenwick.

results.title: Spend and prosper: a portrait of John Maynard Keynes
results.creator_credit: Christopher La Fontaine and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Traces the life of John Maynard Keynes through the eyes of some of the people who knew and worked with him. They include Quentin Bell, J.K. Galbraith and Ninette de Valois. Also spells out some of his economic theories which are in direct opposition to the monetarist policies followed by today’s (1980’s) governments. Narrated by Paul Vaughan.
